body: Thanks @piiswrong . It seems to be related to the `kNotRegisterSymbolic`  flag  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/broadcast_reduce_op-inl.h#L169 , which turns off the symbolic part of these operators.

To get speedup for binary input, I do think we need to have a customized convolution that simply do bit counts, as opposed to using the traditional floating points

Please do the following things
- Add a few unit testcases on the new attribute function to ensure setter/getter works correctly.

I'm not sure if I understand you correctly. In a recent update we updated the Embedding operator to support arbitrary input dimension. Say if you have an input of shape `(10, 20)`, each element is the index of the word in the vocabulary. Then the output will be of shape `(10, 20, D)` where `D` is the embedding dimension. The current (updated) [char-lstm example](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/lstm.py#L66) actually uses this feature.

Maybe I should update the doc for Embedding layer.

For memory efficient gradient updating. @tqchen implemented memory efficient gradients computing. But I am not sure the updating part (optimizer) could be easily implemented for sparse updating as we probably need to modify the kvstore to support sparse matrices (or do we already support?). @tqchen or @mli might be able to give some comments.
This must be due to a recent refactoring of lstm example. I will try to fix it.

I remembered I tried autosummary before and find it does not serve the purpose. But you can try it locally  by simply creating a new doc folder and see if it works
Specifically, autosummary still need you to enumerate the things to summarize in the argument, instead of doing it automatically

Hi, @tqchen  @mli .Thanks for your work firstly. 
I am a question about "**model parallelism**"  ：
I find  the model parallelism of LSTM in mxnet  is implemented by binding one layer just to one gpu. So, is it easy  to  OR  can it implement the model parallelism like **cuda-convnet2** implemented in mxnet? 
Looking forward to your answers, thank you.
I figure it out, it binds the label data when it construct the net, guess I just miss it.

HI, I change it as bellow, the prompt is "AttributeError: 'Executor' object has no attribute 'FeedForward'" . Even though I understand this error, I still don't know how to modify my previous codes. Could you help   @Ldpe2G 

arg_names = softmax.list_arguments()
print arg_names

arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = softmax.infer_shape(data=(1, 1, 100, 100))
arg_dict = dict(zip(arg_names, [mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx=mx.gpu()) for shape in arg_shape]))

arg_dict['con1_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.125, arg_dict['con1_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['con2_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.2, arg_dict['con2_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['con3_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.2, arg_dict['con3_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['con4_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.5, arg_dict['con4_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.0001, arg_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'].shape)

arg_dict['bias'][:] = np.zeros(arg_dict['bias'].shape)
arg_dict['convolution2_bias'][:] = np.zeros(arg_dict['convolution2_bias'].shape)
arg_dict['fullyconnected1_bias'][:] = np.zeros(arg_dict['fullyconnected1_bias'].shape)

num_gpus = 2 
gpus = [mx.gpu(i) for i in range(num_gpus)]

executor = softmax.bind(ctx=gpus, args=arg_dict)

model = executor.FeedForward(
    ctx           = gpus,
    symbol        = softmax,
    num_epoch     = 20,
    learning_rate = 0.00001,
    momentum      = 0.9,
    initializer   = mx.initializer.Normal(sigma=0.01),
    wd            = 0.00001)

```
make HOSTCC=gcc CC=arm-linux-androideabi-gcc NO_LAPACK=1 TARGET=ARMV7
```

Sorry for the late reply. @yajiedesign Could you help to patch the following diff?

```
diff --git a/scala-package/core/src/test/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/ModelParallelSuite.scala b/scala-package/core/src/test/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/ModelParallelSuite.scala
index afbcdca..48dfaef 100644
--- a/scala-package/core/src/test/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/ModelParallelSuite.scala
+++ b/scala-package/core/src/test/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/ModelParallelSuite.scala
@@ -47,7 +47,8 @@ class ModelParallelSuite extends FunSuite with BeforeAndAfterAll {

     exec1.forward()
     exec2.forward()
-    assert(reldiff(exec1.outputs(0), exec2.outputs(0)) < 1e-6f)
+    assert(reldiff(exec1.outputs(0).copyTo(Context.cpu()),
+      exec2.outputs(0).copyTo(Context.cpu())) < 1e-6f)

     val outGrad = NDArray.ones(shape, Context.cpu(1))
     exec1.backward(Array(outGrad))
```

Quite sure, I wasn't actually specifying the `CXX` variable, but it doesn't works even in this case. Could this depend on which android API I choose creating the standalone toolchain? (I'm doing this with android-21).

BTW, more in general, the amalgamation section seems quite outdated w.r.t. the rest of mxnet in the last releases (i.e. the includes that the readme says to remove)
numpy op doesn't support checkpoint loading. You need to reconstruct the model and use mx.init.Load to load the parameter

was due to recent torch update. They changed nn and cunn to nnx and cunnx. You need to modify plugin/torch/torch.mk to reflect this change. We haven't been able to figure out an backward compatible way of fixing this

@lisabug I'm guessing: are you using a `SequentialModule` to chain a convolution module with an RNN module? That assertion would not happen normally. It might happen if, for example, you are using a `Module` and turned on `inputs_need_grad` bit.

What is the difference between `softmax_cross_entropy_loss` and `SoftmaxOutput`?
- `SoftmaxOutput` is softmax combined with logloss (average cross entropy loss) for backwards
- `SoftmaxActivation` is applying only softmax forward&backwards
- `SoftmaxCrossEntropy` is ???

AFAIK the amalgamation readme is a contribution by someone who went through all you are going through now, and posted a guide. I guess this is why it isn't updated.
I assume you mean NDK API 21, and not Android API 21, those a re 2 separate things..
Any way, I don't think there should be a problem with using API 21, as that's how the WhatIsIt demo was built.

What do you mean splitting one layer to multiple GPUs? Do you actually mean data parallelism? Yes we could do data par with model par.

in forward, softmax_cross_entropy output the cross entropy value, while SoftmaxOutput directly outputs the probability.
Thanks for reporting this. these are now fixed

To be clear, this is the correct formal definition of softmax_cross_entropy loss. It also enables you to further composite softmax loss function with other losses like sum them together. However, the SoftmaxOutput still serve as a handy tool to directly being used as terminal node where you need the output result

@piiswrong Is there any sparse matrix available now for this embedding layer? I just read the embedding layer code,and it seem that the problem is still there.

@tuonion What do you mean by splitting a layer into two parts? Do you mean, for example, for a fully connected layer, compute the first half of the output dimension in gpu0 and then the second half of the output dimension in gpu1?

One alternative way is to, in `symbol.py`, define dummy classes like `ConcatDoc` as subclass of `OperatorDoc`, and add examples as docstrings to this class. Then during importing operators, look for subclasses of `OperatorDoc` with matching name. If one found, then append / merge docstring from there to the imported operator. In this way, it will not affect other languages.
It tends to be easier for me to reproduce this kinds of crashes on a Mac OS X.
I think it would be good to set a goal to introduce versioning into libmxnet. Then this kind of breaking changes will not be a disaster for other language bindings.

@pluskid . Yeah, that is what I want to express. I want to implement the model-par  in the mxnet like the Alex Krizhevsky implemented in [cuda-convnet2](https://github.com/akrizhevsky/cuda-convnet2). Is the current mxnet possible to implement it ? 

Thanks a lot.
@pluskid Yes, exactly as you talk. It is possible that something wrong with input data?

@tuonion I think you can just define **two** `FullyConnected` operator each with half of the output dimension and let them live on different GPUs. And then you can combine their results with `Concat`.

Something like this:

``` python
name = # the name of the operator to be defined

doc = "\n".join([x.__doc__ for x in type.__subclasses__(SymbolDoc)
                 if x.__name__ == '%sDoc' % name])

# append doc to docstring of newly defined operator
```

Then you can write

``` python
class ConcatDoc(SymbolDoc):
    """This is some extra doc for the Concat operator in Python.

    blah blah...
    """
    pass
```
agreed

I'm not sure if it's the same problem, but I experienced something similar when i force stop a running script: 
2 of 4 K80's are going into an ERR state: "GPU has fallen off the bus" that only can be solved by cold reboot of the machine.
Could this be related?

import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

data = mx.symbol.Variable(name='data')
conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1', data=data , num_filter=64, kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1))
conv2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv2', data=conv1 , num_filter=64, kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1))
fc1  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = conv2, num_hidden=100)
softmax  = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc1)

arg_names = softmax.list_arguments()
print arg_names

arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = softmax.infer_shape(data=(1, 1, 100, 100))
arg_dict = dict(zip(arg_names, [mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx=mx.gpu()) for shape in arg_shape]))

arg_dict['conv1_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.125, arg_dict['conv1_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['conv2_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.2, arg_dict['conv2_weight'].shape)
arg_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'][:] = np.random.normal(0, 0.0001, arg_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'].shape)

grad_dict = dict(zip(arg_names, [mx.nd.zeros(shape, ctx=mx.gpu()) for shape in arg_shape]))

executor = softmax.bind(ctx=mx.gpu(), args=arg_dict, args_grad=grad_dict, grad_req="write")

lr = mx.lr_scheduler.FactorScheduler(step=10, factor=.9)
optimizer = mx.optimizer.SGD(
    learning_rate = 0.001,
    momentum = 0.9,
    wd = 0.005,
    lr_scheduler = lr,
    clip_gradient = 10)

optim_states_conv1 = optimizer.create_state(0, grad_dict['conv1_weight']) 
optim_states_conv2 = optimizer.create_state(1, grad_dict['conv2_weight']) 
optim_states_fully1 = optimizer.create_state(2, grad_dict['fullyconnected0_weight']) 

max_iters = 1000
for e in range(max_iters):
    executor.forward()
    executor.backward() 
    if e % 100 == 0:
        norm = np.linalg.norm(arg_dict['conv1_weight'].asnumpy())
        print norm
    optimizer.update(0, arg_dict['conv1_weight'], grad_dict['conv1_weight'], optim_states_conv1)
    optimizer.update(1, arg_dict['conv2_weight'], grad_dict['conv2_weight'], optim_states_conv2)
    optimizer.update(2, arg_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'], grad_dict['fullyconnected0_weight'], optim_states_fully1)

Seems I solved the compilation problem, but not sure why at some point the OpenBLAS library was fine w.r.t. the previous attempts. My guess is that since I started over from the very beginning (standalone toolchain creation, oblas compilation etc...) using always the same terminal instance, all the environment variables were correctly set. I'm available to write what I did step-by-step if someone is interested. Also, remember to check if the C++ standard library is correctly configured in the creation of the standalone toolchain, and try to link it in the amalgamation process (I added `-lstdc++` in the Makefile)

Also, it seems that the `jni_libmxnet_predict.so` is needed in your Android Project to make it work, and not only the `libmxnet_predict.so` file.
Just to correct the last statement: ONLY the `jni_libmxnet_predict.so` is needed in the android project.

You can just put all files in a folder, and specify folder a the image path

Most of these errors are due to destruction order of singletons during systems shutdown, so it was not likely that it will affect a real training.  
- The problem in shutdown time is tricky, many of them related to destruction order of CUDA runtime singleton and mxnet library. We already tried to catch most of them. But there is no way we can control destruction order of singletons in other libraries, so things can happen due to this reason.
- Most structures @piiswrong mentioned already uses lazy delete or copy by value in lambda for lazy destructing.

The current way is simply to ignore the error, as if there is ever a synchronization step that print out things or write data to file, it must have already been executed and the effect taken.
